conclusion: Consider the geometry of the wire and the direction of the magnetic field to solve for the Ampere force.
The wire is folded into a shape with segments: Segment ac of length L and Segment cd of length 2L. The current flows from point a to c and then from c to d.
The magnetic force on a segment of wire carrying current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = I (l × B).
Since the magnetic field B is into the plane of the paper, the cross product l × B will be along an axis perpendicular to both l and B.
Calculate the force on segment ac: Length of segment ac is L. The force on this segment is Fac = I (L × B). Since L is vertical and B is perpendicular into the plane, |Fac| = I L B.
Calculate the force on segment cd: Length of segment cd is 2L. The force on this segment is Fcd = I (2L × B). Since 2L is horizontal and B is perpendicular into the plane, |Fcd| = 2I L B.
Determine the net force: The forces Fac and Fcd act perpendicular to each other. Using Pythagoras' theorem, |Fnet| = √((I L B)^2 + (2I L B)^2) = √(5I^2 L^2 B^2) = √5 I L B.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on this current-carrying wire is √5 I L B.
